description: From Middle English fleumatik, flewmatik, flematik, fleumatyke, flewmatyk, from Old French fleumatique, from Latin phlegmaticus, from Ancient Greek φλεγματικός (phlegmatikós), from φλέγμα (phlégma). Spelling later altered to resemble the word's Latin and Greek roots, with modern pronunciation following this new spelling.

adjectives.description: phlegmatic (comparative more phlegmatic, superlative most phlegmatic)

entries.meaning: Not easily excited to action or passion; calm; sluggish.
examples: Their friendship (immortalized in a splendid volume of letters that has clearly served as one of Ms. von Trotta's sources) is a fascinating study in cultural and temperamental contrast, an impulsive and witty American paired with a steady, phlegmatic German.

entries.meaning: Generating, causing, or full of phlegm.
One who has a phlegmatic disposition.
